Article.Abstract: Antiviral cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTL) may play a role in clearance of hepatitis C virus (HCV)-infected cells and thereby cause hepatocellular injury during acute and chronic HCV infection. The aim of this study was to identify HLA-A2.1-restricted HCV T-cell epitopes and to evaluate whether anti-HCV-specific CTL are present during chronic hepatitis C. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells from four HLA-A2-positive patients with chronic hepatitis C and from two individuals after recovery from HCV infection were tested against a panel of HCV-encoded peptides derived from different regions of the genome, including some peptides containing HLA-A2.1 binding motifs. HLA-A2-negative patients with chronic hepatitis C as well as healthy HLA-A2-positive (anti-HCV-negative) donors served as controls. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells stimulated repeatedly with several HCV-encoded peptides (three in core, one in NS4B, and one in NS5B) yielded cytolytic responses. All four HLA-A2-positive patients with active infection had CTL specific for at least one of the identified epitopes, whereas two patients who had recovered from HCV infection had almost no CTL responses. Monoclonal antibody blocking experiments performed for two epitopes demonstrated a class I- and HLA-A2-restricted CTL response. CTL epitopes could partially be predicted by HLA-A2 binding motifs and more reliably by quantitative HLA-A2.1 molecule binding assays. Most of the identified epitopes could also be produced via the endogenous pathway. Specific CTL against multiple, mostly highly conserved epitopes of HCV were detected during chronic HCV infection. This finding may be important for further investigations of the immunopathogenesis of HCV, the development of potential therapies against HCV on the basis of induction or enhancement of cellular immunity, and the design of vaccines.
Article.ArticleTitle: Patients with chronic hepatitis C have circulating cytotoxic T cells which recognize hepatitis C virus-encoded peptides binding to HLA-A2.1 molecules.
Article.Affiliations: Liver Diseases Section, National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, Bethesda, Maryland.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Chronic Disease; HLA-A2 Antigen(immunology); Hepacivirus(immunology); Hepatitis C(immunology); Humans; Molecular Sequence Data; Protein Binding; T-Lymphocytes, Cytotoxic(immunology)
Article.Comments: Data originally imported from the Database of Functional Molecular Immunology, FIMM (http://sdmc.lit.org.sg:8080/fimm/) and from the HLA Ligand Database (http://hlaligand.ouhsc.edu/)

PBMC were stimulated four times in vitro with the 16-mer peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL lines repeatedly stimulated with a 16-mer, HLA-A2.1 binding motif-containing peptide (AACRAAGLQDCTMLVC) from the HCV NS4B-NS5B region were shown not to recognize this peptide. This peptide was shown to weakly bind to HLA-A2.1 molecules.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were stimulated four times in vitro with the 16-mer peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL lines repeatedly stimulated with a 16-mer, HLA-A2.1 binding motif-containing peptide (AACRAAGLQDCTMLVC) from the HCV NS4B-NS5B region were shown to optimally recognize this epitope. The epitope was also shown to strongly bind to HLA-A2.1 molecules.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were stimulated twice in vitro with the peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL from HLA-A2 positive patients were found to react against a 16-mer, HLA-A2.1 binding motif-containing peptide from the HCV NS4B-NS5B region. This minimal reactive epitope was then determined by testing smaller peptides covering this 16-mer.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were stimulated four to six times in vitro with the a 16-mer, HLA-A2.1 binding motif-containing peptide (AACRAAGLQDCTMLVC) from the HCV NS4B-NS5B region.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL responses of patients with active disease were analyzed against target cells infected with recombinant vaccinia virus coding for part of NS2 and the entire NS3-NS5B region.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were stimulated six times in vitro with the peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL responses were analyzed in four patients with active disease and two individuals who recovered and had no virological or biochemical signs of ongoing infection. The peptide was chosen for the presence of an HLA-A2.1 binding motif.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were stimulated four times in vitro with the peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL responses of a patient with active disease were analyzed against target cells infected with recombinant vaccinia virus coding for core, E1, E2, and part of NS2.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were stimulated four times in vitro with the peptide.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTL responses of a patient with active disease were analyzed against target cells infected with recombinant vaccinia virus coding for core, E1, E2, and part of NS2.
